Award.AwardTitle: Analysis of Survival Data using Copula Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main objective of this research is to use Archimedean copula models to analyze survival data. The proposed strategies are useful in medical research and financial data analysis. The investigator will address three different problems. The first problem is to solve the identifiability problem for Archimedean copula models for dependent censored data. The second problem concerns left truncated bivariate data. The investigator will explore ways to best estimate the unknown parameters in Archimedean copula models using truncated bivariate data. A model selection procedure for Archimedean copula models will also be investigated. The last problem is to establish guidelines for selecting models belonging to Archimedean copula family based on survival data. Research will be conducted to demonstrate the performance of the proposed strategies.

The proposed methods and strategies are motivated by clinical trials involving dependent censoring problem and the study of the correlated bivariate survival data in AIDS research. The results of this project will be helpful for determining the underlying relationship between random variables when they are subject to different censoring patterns. The theoretic results will contribute to the advancement of the statistical theory on correlation studies and deepen the understanding of the dependence structure of Archimedean copula models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research has three major aims. They are

 1.   To address the identifiability problems in modeling dependent censoring data using Archimedean copula models.

 2.    To addrss the parameter estimation problem in analyzing left truncated bivariate data.

 3.    To explore the implications and interpretations in applications of different Archimedean copula  Models.

The research in Aim 1 is important in that it can solve the nonidentifiabilty issue for Archimedean copula models posed by Tsiatis (1975) and Wang (2012). Before this research, dependent censoring and competing risks problems were serious issues in medical research area. If the failure time and censoring time are independent, we can obtain consistent estimators of marginal survival functions using Kalan-Meier estimates. In practice, however, this assumption may not hold: censoring time may be dependent upon failure time if they are both related to the disease or some other common factors. In that case, the survival function estimates will not be consistent if we still assume the independence between the failure time and the censoring time. Wang, Chandra, Xu and Sun (2015) have proposed a set of identification conditions under which such dependence can be identified. Based on this result, we can consistently estimate the survival functions for both the failure time and the censoring time.

The research in Aim 2 is important in that it can solve the parameter estimation problem for bivariate data under left censoring/truncation. In this research, we propose estimation strategies to analyze left truncated bivariate data using Archimedean copula models. Our strategies is a generalization of the methodology proposed in Wang (2007). A model selection procedure for Archimedean copula models has also been proposed for this type of data. The methodology has been demonstrated by simulations and the analysis of an AIDS data. Our paper (Wang, Chandra and Jia 2015 has been listed below).

The research in Aim 3 is significant as it tells us about the implications of the assumptions of Archimedean copula models. We have developed goodness-of-fit tests and model selection procedures based on the formulas of marginal survival functions of Archimedean copula models we have derived in Wang (2014). The results have been reported in Wang and Chandra (2015).

The major outcomes of the award can be summaried as follows:

Publications:

Antai Wang. (2012) On the nonidentifiability property of Archimedean copula models under dependent censoring. Statistics & Probability Letters 82 621-625.
Antai Wang (2014) Properties of the Marginal Survival Functions for Dependent Censored Data under an assumed Archimedean Copula.  Journal of Multivariate Analysis, 129, 57-68.
Antai Wang, Krishnendu Chandra, Ruihua Xu, Junfeng Sun (2015) The identifiability of dependent competing risks models induced by bivariate frailty models. Scandinavian Journal of Statististics, 42, 427-437.

The following two papers are still under review: 1. Antai Wang, Krishnendu Chandra, Xiyang Jia (2015) The Analysis of Left Censored Bivariate Data Using Frailty Models (Submitted). 2. Antai Wang, Krishnendu Chandra (2015) Goodness-of-fit tests and model selection procedures for Archimedean copula models (Submitted).

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2015
Modified by: Antai Wang

The research in Aim 1 is important in that it can solve the nonidentifiabilty issue for Archimedean copula models posed by Tsiatis (1975) and Wang (2012).
